24 January 2015

The Language Features of JavaScript that Create Closure

  1. a closure function closes over (encloses) the closure-scoped variables
  2. the declaration is returned within another function
  3. references a variable from its context (the containing function)
  4. when the closure function is executed, it can access the variables referenced in even though the containing function has already finished execution

function properties (language features) that allow for closures in JS:

  1. fn1 can/must explicitly return value (or value gets GCed)
  2. fn1 can return fn2 as explicit return value
  3. fn2 can retain access to the context in which it was created
  4. fn1 returns fn2 as explict value
  5. fn2 references variable A in fn1
  6. fn1 gets executed and stored in variable as fn2
  7. variable A disappears when execution is done
  8. fn2 gets executed
  9. fn2 can access variable A, even though the fn1’s execution context (intuitively) should have disappeared at this point

Scopes

  1. scope = part of program where a binding between a variable and value is valid
  2. lexical scope = regions of source code where variable name reference has meaning (no access errors)
  3. default scope in JavaScript is global
  4. ‘{‘ of a function declaration delimits the entry to a new lexical scope
  5. lexical scope enforces access rules
  6. scopes can be nested
  7. variables are either global or local to a single function (lexically scoped)
  8. in-memory (dynamic) scope = in-memory storage sytem (data structure) for holding variables and their values
  9. in-memory scope structures are called execution contexts
  10. in-memory scopes == dynamic scopes == execution contexts
  11. lexical scopes have one-to-many relationships with in-memory scopes (1 lexical scope for the code—n dynamic scopes, with one for each invocation of the function associated with that scope program run
  12. in-memory datastores will be built to keep track of all variables available to function objects
  13. an in-memory datastore is created anew for every invocation of a function to isolate the running of each function
  14. thus, for each lexical scope there could be 0-many in-memory scopes/execution contexts (depending on how many times the function has been executed)
  15. the current in-memory scope/execution context is where the interpreter first does lookup
  16. the execution context has a key-value mapping inside it

Closures

  1. closure = a function object that retains ongoing access to the variables of the context in which it was created
  2. a function object (the function itself, uninvoked) that was created within another function
  3. this inner function object is just a reference to the function object that you invoke later!
